title: The Hottest New Baseball Coaches Were Born During the FDR Administration
text:
Phil Regan and Charlie Manuel coached together with the Cleveland Indians in 1999. Regan was in charge of the pitchers. Manuel handled the hitters. At the time, the average age of a pitching or hitting coach in Major League Baseball was under 50-years-old. Regan and Manuel were 62 and 55, respectively, making them old for their jobs by any measurable standard.

Now two decades have passed and the sport has only gotten younger, from the players to the managers to the executives. Yet when the New York Mets and Philadelphia Phillies found themselves on the verge of collapse this summer and in the position to hire any young hotshot on the market, they took a different approach. They brought back Regan, now 82, and Manuel, who is 75—even though they are old enough to be the grandfathers of almost every player on the roster.

And here’s the crazy part: The Mets and Phillies surged after their arrival, helping both teams stay in the thick of the playoff race.

“Age doesn’t matter,” Mets closer Seth Lugo said. “I’m close with my grandpa.”

SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS What can older coaches do to related to today’s younger players? Join the conversation below.

The qualifications for major-league coaches have changed dramatically in recent years, with the rise of data and technology-based instruction ushering in a new breed of candidates. Seven first-time hitting and pitching coaches hired this past off-season never even played in the minors, their statistical and kinesthetic expertise outweighing their lack of experience.

Regan and Manuel are the exact opposite. They might still be relatively new to the latest gadgets and metrics—but what they do have is knowledge and skills acquired through full careers as players and teachers, characteristics that have been devalued.

Regan, a grandfather of 18, pitched in the majors against Ted Williams and Mickey Mantle. His manager with the 1960 Detroit Tigers, Jimmy Dykes, was born in 1896. He got his first pitching coach gig with the Seattle Mariners at age 47, and he says he felt on the older side then. That was 35 years ago.

Manuel, 75, made his big-league debut in April 1969. Like Regan, it has been 20 years since Manuel had served as a coach in the majors, but he says not much has changed: He still often refers to Williams’s book, “The Science of Hitting,” of which he owns around a dozen copies.

“Experience definitely counts in this game,” Manuel said.

Regan and Manuel have plenty of that, and it’s hard to argue with the results.

When the Mets fired pitching coach Dave Eiland on June 20, their vaunted staff had a collective ERA of 4.67, 20th in the majors and third-to-last in the National League. The team was below .500 and, at best, on the fringe of the wild-card chase.

The announcement that Regan would replace Eiland immediately inspired curious headlines and plenty of talk-radio snark. Regan said that when he arrived, he told the Mets, “I think I need No. 82 on my back, because every article I read said, ‘Phil Regan, 82, named pitching coach.’” (He wound up going with No. 58.)

The jokes have stopped. The Mets entered Tuesday with a 3.95 ERA under Regan, sixth-best in baseball over that span.

“There’s instant credibility when you talk about Phil Regan,” said Mickey Callaway, the Mets’ 44-year-old manager. “He’s done everything in the game.”

New York Mets pitching coach Phil Regan jogs back to the dugout. Photo: tannen maury/epa/Shutterstock

Manuel took over for John Mallee on Aug. 13, moving to the dugout from the front office, where he served as a senior adviser to general manager Matt Klentak. Before that, he led the Phillies to a World Series championship as their manager in 2008. When Manuel started as hitting coach, the Phillies ranked 18th in baseball in runs per game and had slipped into fourth place in the division.

They entered Tuesday ranked fifth in the majors in runs per game during Manuel’s tenure. Both the Mets and Phillies have seen their production improve after a coaching change, vaulting them into wild-card contention with less than a month remaining in the regular season. It has caught the attention of the industry, which has perhaps underestimated the significance of experience.

“Baseball’s still the same,” Regan said. “It doesn’t change. You just have more tools.”

The biggest question surrounding Regan and Manuel was how they would adjust to coaching in a paradigm dominated by analytics after spending a lifetime in baseball without them.

Regan has dedicated himself to understanding the modern thinking ever since he returned to the Mets’ organization as a minor-league coach in 2009. He recognizes that many of his peers dismiss analytics, but he knows that if he hadn’t stayed current, his baseball career would’ve ended years ago. It’s for that reason, Mets reliever Luis Avilán said, “Whenever I talk to him, I’m not thinking, ‘Come on, this guy is so old.’”

“The computer age is here and has been here for a while, so you might as well learn it,” Regan said. “You’ve got to keep learning.”

Manuel says he, too, has bulked up his knowledge of how coaches use technology to help hitters, though he doesn’t consider himself an expert. His biggest strength, players say, is how he helps them navigate the mental challenges of baseball—perhaps the most important job of any hitting or pitching coach.

That’s one area where Manuel believes younger, inexperienced coaches struggle. While he has no doubt of their ability to teach swing mechanics, they haven’t necessarily helped hitters mired in a dreadful slump regain their confidence or deal with the pressure of hitting in crucial September games.

“The hardest situation you’ll ever see in baseball, he has already seen it,” Phillies shortstop Jean Segura said of Manuel. “And he already got it done.”

To build a rapport with players more than 50 years their junior, Regan and Manuel have taken to talking to players about the past, regaling them with stories of Williams and Harmon Killebrew and Carl Yastrzemski. Regan recently had an in-depth conversation with pitchers about the reserve clause, the creation of free agency and the early days of the players’ union.

It seems unlikely either coach will return to his post in 2020. Their teams will probably seek long-term solutions. But Regan and Manuel have done enough to force other teams to consider having an old-timer on their staff moving forward. At the very least, maybe they won’t snicker the next time somebody like Regan or Manuel comes along.

“People don’t respect their elders like they used to,” Lugo said. “I think that says a lot.”

Write to Jared Diamond at jared.diamond@wsj.com
description: Charlie Manuel, age 75, and Phil Regan, age 82, drew snickers when they were hired, but have proven that experience can be a valuable asset.
